{{short description|Emotional, physical, sexual or verbal violence against transgender persons}} {{Transgender sidebar}}{{Discrimination sidebar|state=collapsed}} '''Trans bashing''' is the act of [[victimizing]] a person emotionally, physically, sexually, or verbally because they are [[transgender]].<ref>[http://www.news.com.au/heraldsun/story/0,21985,20774504-5005961,00.html Guilty plea over transsexual bashing] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080502173830/http://www.news.com.au/heraldsun/story/0%2C21985%2C20774504-5005961%2C00.html |date=2008-05-02 }} By Mariza O'Keefe in ''Herald Sun''</ref> The term has also been applied to [[hate speech]] directed at transgender people<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtonblade.com/2007/4-27/view/columns/10484.cfm|title=Page not found - Washington Blade: Gay News, Politics, LGBT Rights|website=Washington Blade: Gay News, Politics, LGBT Rights|access-date=2007-11-28|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120311144020/http://www.washingtonblade.com/2007/4-27/view/columns/10484.cfm|archive-date=2012-03-11|url-status=live}}</ref> and at depictions of transgender people in the media that reinforce negative stereotypes about them.<ref>{{cite news |first=Mary|last=McNamara|title=Transgender Artists, Work Gaining Acceptance|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=2001-02-08}}</ref> Trans and [[non-binary gender]] adolescents can experience bashing in the form of [[bullying]] and [[harassment]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Reisner|first1=Sari L.|last2=Greytak|first2=Emily A.|last3=Parsons|first3=Jeffrey T.|last4=Ybarra|first4=Michele|date=2015|title=Gender Minority Social Stress in Adolescence: Disparities in Adolescent Bullying and Substance Use by Gender Identity|journal=Journal of Sex Research|volume=52|issue=3|pages=243–256|doi=10.1080/00224499.2014.886321|issn=0022-4499|pmc=4201643|pmid=24742006}}</ref> When compared to their [[cisgender]] peers, trans and non-binary gender youth are at increased risk for victimization, which has been shown to increase their risk of [[Substance Use & Misuse|substance]] abuse.<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Reisner|first1=Sari L.|last2=Greytak|first2=Emily A.|last3=Parsons|first3=Jeffrey T.|last4=Ybarra|first4=Michele|date=2015|title=Gender Minority Social Stress in Adolescence: Disparities in Adolescent Bullying and Substance Use by Gender Identity|journal=Journal of Sex Research|volume=52|issue=3|pages=243–256|doi=10.1080/00224499.2014.886321|issn=0022-4499|pmc=4201643|pmid=24742006}}</ref>
Discrimination, including physical or sexual violence against trans people due to [[transphobia]] or [[homophobia]], is a common occurrence for trans people.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://docs.google.com/viewer?url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040612144850/http://www.opha.on.ca/ppres/2003-06_pp.pdf|title=2003-06_pp.pdf|website=docs.google.com|access-date=2019-04-10|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160518222557/https://docs.google.com/viewer?url=https%3A%2F%2Fweb.archive.org%2Fweb%2F20040612144850%2Fhttp%3A%2F%2Fwww.opha.on.ca%2Fppres%2F2003-06_pp.pdf|archive-date=2016-05-18|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>Hill, D.B. (2001). Genderism, transphobia, and gender bashing: A framework for interpreting anti-transgender violence. In B. Wallace, & R. Carter (Eds.). A multicultural approach for understanding and dealing with violence: A handbook for psychologists and educators. Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage Publishing.</ref><ref>Namaste, V.K. (2000a). Invisible lives: The erasure of transsexual and transgendered people. Chicago: University of Chicago Press.</ref> Hate crimes against trans people are common even recently, and "in some instances, inaction by police or other government officials leads to the untimely deaths of transgender victims."<ref name="cider">{{cite journal |last=Frye|first=Phyllis|date=Fall 2000|title=The International Bill of Gender Rights vs. The Cide House Rules: Transgenders struggle with the courts over what clothing they are allowed to wear on the job, which restroom they are allowed to use on the job, their right to marry, and the very definition of their sex|journal=William and Mary Journal of Women and the Law|volume=7|pages=139–145}}</ref>
An infamous incident was the December 1993 rape and murder of [[Brandon Teena]], a young [[trans man]], by two male friends after they found out that he had been assigned female at birth.<ref name="trutv5">{{cite web|url=http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/notorious_murders/not_guilty/brandon/5.html|title=Teena Brandon|last=Ramsland|first=Katherine|publisher=[[TruTV]]|pages=5|accessdate=2009-02-22|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131214094602/http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/notorious_murders/not_guilty/brandon/5.html|archivedate=2013-12-14}}</ref> These events gained international attention after being depicted in the film ''[[Boys Don't Cry (film)|Boys Don't Cry]]'' (1999), which earned [[Hilary Swank]] an [[Academy Award for Best Actress]].
== Differentiation from gay bashing ==
Unlike [[gay bashing]], trans bashing is committed because of the target's actual or perceived [[gender identity]], not [[sexual orientation]].{{Dubious |Not about gender identity |reason=No, it's because of their transgressive gender expression, irrespective of a cis or trans identity |date=December 2017}} However, a trans person may be gay bashed if the person perceives them as gay rather than transgender.{{citation needed |date=December 2017}}
At least since the [[Stonewall riots]] in 1969, people from the greater trans communities have often been politically aligned with the lesbian, gay, and bisexual communities.<ref>Kay Dayus, Transgenders Protest HRC Exec's Visit to Houston, Hous. Voice, Sept. 29, 2000</ref> However, researchers and some activists from the greater trans communities argue trans bashing should be categorized separately from violence committed on the basis of sexual orientation ("gay-bashing").<ref name="cider"/><ref>Discrimination and Hate Crimes Against Gender Variant People, It's Time Illinois . . . Political Action for the Gender Variant Community (May 2000)</ref> Anti-trans bias crimes have been conceptually and characteristically distinguished from homophobic crimes in the scholarly research.<ref>Anti-Transgender Hate Crimes: The Challenge for Law Enforcement, at http://jointheimpactma.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/Victimization-Study-Report.pdf {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110819025320/http://jointheimpactma.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/Victimization-Study-Report.pdf |date=2011-08-19 }}</ref> One argument is that conflating violence against trans peoples with violence against gay people erases the identities of people in the greater trans communities and the truth of what happens to them. However, campaigns against gay bashing and trans bashing are often seen as having a common cause.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.workers.org/ww/1998/bashing1008.php|title=Workers World Oct. 8, 1998: Zero tolerance for gay-trans bashing|website=www.workers.org|access-date=2007-11-28|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080502153653/http://www.workers.org/ww/1998/bashing1008.php|archive-date=2008-05-02|url-status=live}}</ref>
In one case, perpetrators accused of hate crimes against trans people have tried to use a [[trans panic]] defense, an extension of [[gay panic defense]].<ref name="TRTH">[https://books.google.com/books?id=SiaNoJ3puyQC&pg=PA47&dq=%22gwen+araujo%22&lr=&as_brr=3#PPA47,M1 ''Transpeople: Repudiation, Trauma, Healing''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150926110512/https://books.google.com/books?id=SiaNoJ3puyQC&pg=PA47&dq=%22gwen+araujo%22&lr=&as_brr=3#PPA47,M1 |date=2015-09-26 }} by Christopher A. Shelley.</ref><ref name="TMCIAC">[http://www.ebar.com/news/article.php?sec=news&article=153 "Two murder convictions in Araujo case"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090201000001/http://www.ebar.com/news/article.php?sec=news&article=153 |date=2009-02-01 }}, Zak Szymanski; ''[[Bay Area Reporter]]'' 15 September 2005.</ref> The jury deadlocked, but there is evidence they rejected the trans-panic defense. One law journal provided an analysis of the trans-panic defense, arguing in part that the emotional premise of a trans panic defense (shock at discovering unexpected genitals) is different from the emotional premise of a gay panic defense (shock at being propositioned by a member of the same sex, perhaps because of one's repressed homosexuality).<ref>{{cite journal |last=Steinberg|first=Victoria L.|date=Spring 2005|title=A Heat of Passion Offense: Emotions and Bias in "Trans Panic" Mitigation Claims: Hiding From Humanity|journal=Boston College Third World Law Journal|volume=25}}</ref>
== Laws covering gender identity ==
===International=== The United Nations adopted their [[Universal Declaration of Human Rights]] in 1948 as the first global declaration of human rights.<ref name=UDHR>{{cite web|title=The Universal Declaration of Human Rights|url=https://www.un.org/en/documents/udhr|website=un.org|access-date=2015-03-18|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150317061858/http://www.un.org/en/documents/udhr/|archive-date=2015-03-17|url-status=live}}</ref> There are a number of articles in the declaration that have been suggested to specifically pertain to transgender people and violence (including, but not limited to, physical, psychological, legal, systemic, emotional, and political violence), although LGBT rights are not explicitly outlined in the document.
* Article 2 entitles individuals to all of the rights and freedoms set forth in the declaration "without distinction of any kind, such as race, colour, sex, language, religion, political or other opinion, national or social origin, property, birth or other status". * Article 5 states that "[n]o one shall be subjected to torture or to cruel, [[inhuman or degrading treatment]] or punishment." * Article 7 states that "[a]ll are equal before the law and are entitled without any discrimination to equal protection of the law. All are entitled to equal protection against any discrimination in violation of this Declaration and against any incitement to such discrimination". * Article 9 bans "[[arbitrary arrest and detention|arbitrary arrest]], detention or exile" (which, according to Article 2, is protected from distinction based on identity or belief). * Article 20 states that "[e]veryone has the right to freedom of opinion and expression; this right includes freedom to hold opinions without interference and to seek, receive and impart information and ideas through any media and regardless of frontiers."<ref name="AI Human Rights">{{cite web|title=About LGBT Human Rights|url=http://www.amnestyusa.org/our-work/issues/lgbt-rights/about-lgbt-human-rights|website=amnestyusa.org|publisher=Amnesty International|access-date=2015-03-18|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150310153212/http://www.amnestyusa.org/our-work/issues/lgbt-rights/about-lgbt-human-rights|archive-date=2015-03-10|url-status=live}}</ref>
===North America===
====United States==== [[File:Map of LGBT-related hate crime law in the United States.svg|thumb|right|Current U.S. LGBT [[hate crimes laws in the United States|hate crimes laws]] by state. A national hate crimes law encompasses both sexual orientation and gender identity. {{legend|#800080|Sexual orientation and gender identity recognized in state hate crimes law}} {{legend|#0000ff|Sexual orientation recognized in state hate crimes law}} {{legend|#00ffff|Sexual orientation recognized for data collection about hate crimes}} {{legend|#cccccc|State hate crimes law uninclusive of sexual orientation or gender identity}}]]
In the United States, currently seventeen states plus the District of Columbia have hate crime laws protecting people victimized on the basis of their gender identity (they are [[California]], [[Colorado]], [[Connecticut]], [[Delaware]], [[Hawaii]], [[Illinois]], [[Maryland]], [[Massachusetts]], [[Minnesota]], [[Missouri]], [[Nevada]], [[New Jersey]], [[New Mexico]], [[Oregon]], [[Rhode Island]], [[Vermont]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]], and [[Washington, D.C.]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lgbtmap.org/equality-maps/hate_crime_laws|title=Hate Crime Laws|access-date=2015-11-02|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151117032344/http://www.lgbtmap.org/equality-maps/hate_crime_laws|archive-date=2015-11-17|url-status=live}}</ref>
In the late 2000s in [[Seattle]]'s [[gay village]] of [[Capitol Hill, Seattle, Washington|Capitol Hill]], there was evidence of an increase in incidents of trans bashing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://spectator.seattleu.edu/news/story.aspx?ID=14050|title=Gentrification ousting local gay community|last=Holt|first=Emily|publisher=The Spectator|accessdate=2 January 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080502105800/http://spectator.seattleu.edu/news/story.aspx?ID=14050|archivedate=2 May 2008}}</ref>
The [[Matthew Shepard Act]] expanded the federal hate crime laws to include gender, gender identity, and sexual orientation. In order to qualify as a federal hate crime in the United States, the crime must include successful or attempted bodily injury due to the use of firearm, explosives, weapons, fire, or incendiary devices.<ref name="18 U.S. Code § 249 (a)(2) (a) – “Hate Crime Acts”">{{cite web|title=18 U.S. Code § 249 (a)(2) (a) – "Hate Crime Acts"|url=http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/USCODE-2011-title18/pdf/USCODE-2011-title18-partI-chap13-sec249.pdf|website=Government Publishing Office|publisher=Government Publishing Office|accessdate=28 April 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160307144216/https://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/USCODE-2011-title18/pdf/USCODE-2011-title18-partI-chap13-sec249.pdf|archive-date=7 March 2016|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Hate crimes are covered by state, rather than federal laws unless the victim or defendant travel across state lines or national borders; using an interstate commuting route; the weapon has been brought across state lines; or if the conduct interferes with or otherwise affects commerce across state lines.<ref name="18 U.S. Code § 249 (a)(2) (a) – “Hate Crime Acts”" /> This means that, unless hate crimes under the federal definition occur in a way that does not just affect one state, states have the freedom to implement their own hate crime laws. The protections of these laws range widely. Pennsylvania, for example, has not included gender identity in their hate crime protections since it was rescinded from the law in 2008.<ref name="Philadelphia Hate Crime Laws">{{cite news|last1=Giampolo|first1=Angela|title=Changing the State of Hate Crime-Laws in Philadelphia|url=http://www.thelegalintelligencer.com/id=1202671537351/Changing-the-State-of-HateCrime-Laws-in-Pennsylvania?slreturn=20140923231944|accessdate=28 April 2015|agency=The Legal Intelligencer|publisher=The Legal Intelligencer|date=29 September 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170629171430/http://www.thelegalintelligencer.com/id=1202671537351/Changing-the-State-of-HateCrime-Laws-in-Pennsylvania?slreturn=20140923231944|archive-date=29 June 2017|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
====='Bathroom bills' to enforce gendered bathroom use=====
{{Main|Bathroom bill}}
Bathroom bills are bills proposed with relation to bathroom access and gender identity.<ref name="Bathroom bills definition">{{cite web|last1=Sprigg|first1=Peter|title="Gender Identity" Protections ("Bathroom Bills")|url=http://www.frc.org/onepagers/gender-identity-protections-bathroom-bills|website=Family Research Council|publisher=Family Research Council|access-date=2015-04-06|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150411193738/http://www.frc.org/onepagers/gender-identity-protections-bathroom-bills|archive-date=2015-04-11|url-status=live}}</ref> There have been a number of [[Bathroom bill#United States|bills proposed in the United States]] intended to limit access to restrooms for those who do not identify with the sex on their birth certificate. Some of these bills are justified with the rationale of protecting cisgender women from violent acts committed by cisgender men entering their facilities under the pretense of identifying as transgender women, although there is no evidence thus far of any incidences of this.<ref name="Florida lawmaker">{{cite web|last1=Bixby|first1=Scott|title=This Lawmaker Wants to Make It Illegal for Transgender People to Use Bathrooms|url=http://mic.com/articles/110314/this-lawmaker-wants-to-make-it-illegal-for-trans-people-to-use-bathrooms|publisher=Mic|access-date=2015-04-06|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150316222440/http://mic.com/articles/110314/this-lawmaker-wants-to-make-it-illegal-for-trans-people-to-use-bathrooms|archive-date=2015-03-16|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="Debunking myth about bathroom bills">{{cite news|last1=Maza|first1=Carlos|title=Debunking The Big Myth About Transgender-Inclusive Bathrooms|url=http://mediamatters.org/blog/2014/03/20/debunking-the-big-myth-about-transgender-inclus/198530|agency=Media Matters for America|access-date=2015-04-06|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150331045813/http://mediamatters.org/blog/2014/03/20/debunking-the-big-myth-about-transgender-inclus/198530|archive-date=2015-03-31|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="Effects of bathroom bills">{{cite news|last1=Brinker|first1=Luke|title=One Month Later: How California's Transgender Student Law Is Affecting Public Schools|url=http://equalitymatters.org/blog/201401310002|agency=Equality Matters|access-date=2015-04-06|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150419200416/http://equalitymatters.org/blog/201401310002|archive-date=2015-04-19|url-status=live}}</ref>
Some transgender people are content, and may even prefer, using [[Unisex public toilet|gender-neutral bathrooms]], but others expect the right to use the bathroom of the gender with which they identify. The Gay, Lesbian, and Straight Education Network found that singling out trans students by offering them alternative facility options may backfire by increasing their chances of disengaging from school or dropping out entirely.<ref name="GLSEN Study trans in school">{{cite web|title=Harsh Realities: The Experiences of Transgender Youth in Our Nation|url=http://glsen.org/sites/default/files/Harsh%20Realities.pdf|website=Gay Lesbian Straight Education Network|publisher=GLSEN|access-date=2015-04-06|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150319003743/http://glsen.org/sites/default/files/Harsh%20Realities.pdf|archive-date=2015-03-19|url-status=live}}</ref>
=====Harassment of transgender people in bathrooms=====
It is transgender people who are likely to be harassed in bathrooms by cisgender people, not the other way around. In one survey, 70 percent of the transgender respondents had faced discrimination when attempting to use a restroom of their gender identity, including "denial of access to facilities, verbal harassment, and physical assault."<ref name="Williams Institute Study Bathroom access">{{cite web|last1=Herman|first1=Jody|title=Williams Institute|url=http://williamsinstitute.law.ucla.edu/wp-content/uploads/Herman-Gendered-Restrooms-and-Minority-Stress-June-2013.pdf|publisher=Williams Institute|access-date=2015-04-06|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161122015434/http://williamsinstitute.law.ucla.edu/wp-content/uploads/Herman-Gendered-Restrooms-and-Minority-Stress-June-2013.pdf|archive-date=2016-11-22|url-status=live}}</ref> An example of such harassment occurred in 2018, when [[United States House of Representatives elections in California, 2018#District 44|California Republican Congressional candidate Jazmina Saavedra]] said she heard the "voice of a man" from a locked stall in the women's restroom of a fast-food restaurant in Los Angeles and filmed herself chasing the person out of the restaurant with assistance from the restaurant manager. In the video, Saavedra said she was prepared to use pepper spray and a stungun against the transgender woman.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Broverman|first1=Neal|title=Trump Supporter Broadcasts Live as She Chases Trans Woman Out of Bathroom|url=https://www.advocate.com/transgender/2018/5/17/trump-supporter-broadcasts-live-she-chases-trans-woman-out-bathroom|accessdate=18 May 2018|publisher=The Advocate|date=17 May 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180518074838/https://www.advocate.com/transgender/2018/5/17/trump-supporter-broadcasts-live-she-chases-trans-woman-out-bathroom|archive-date=18 May 2018|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref> This kind of tactic can result in public [[outing]] of a transgender person's current or former gender identity.
One survey of transgender populations conducted in [[Washington, DC]], by the group ''DC Trans Coalition'', "found that 70 percent of survey respondents report experiencing verbal harassment, assault, and being denied access to public toilets."<ref name=":0">{{cite journal|last=Herman|first=Jody|date=June 2013|title=Gendered Restrooms and Minority Stress: The Public Regulation of Gender and Its Impact on Transgender People's Lives|url=http://williamsinstitute.law.ucla.edu/wp-content/uploads/Herman-Gendered-Restrooms-and-Minority-Stress-June-2013.pdf|journal=Journal of Public Management & Social Policy|volume=19|issue=1|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161122015434/http://williamsinstitute.law.ucla.edu/wp-content/uploads/Herman-Gendered-Restrooms-and-Minority-Stress-June-2013.pdf|archivedate=November 22, 2016}}</ref> It also found that "54 percent of all respondents reported having some sort of physical problem from trying to avoid using public toilets, such as dehydration, kidney infections, and urinary tract infections" making access to safe restrooms a public health issue.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":6">Penner, Barbara. ''Bathroom''. Reaktion Books, 2013.</ref>
On February 23, 2020, a restaurant patron in Toa Baja, Puerto Rico made a police report that a transgender woman had entered the women's bathroom. Police arrived at the restaurant and spoke to the transgender woman. Someone filmed the police interaction and posted the video to social media. Later that day, the transgender woman—Alexa Negrón Luciano, also known as Neulisa Luciano Ruiz—was murdered.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnn.com/2020/02/29/us/alexa-puerto-rico-transgender-killing/index.html|title=A transgender woman's brutal murder has shocked Puerto Rico and renewed a conversation about transphobia|last1=Kaur|first1=Harmeet|last2=Rivera|first2=Rafy|date=29 February 2020|website=CNN|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-03-01}}</ref>
===Europe===
====Malta====
Malta passed the 'Gender Identity, Gender Expression, and Sex Characteristics Act in 2015. This bill states that all citizens of Malta have the right to # The recognition of their gender identity; # The free development of their person according to their gender identity; # Be treated according to their gender identity and, particularly, to be identified in that way in the documents providing their identity therein; and # Bodily integrity and physical autonomy.<ref name="Malta Transgender Bill" />
This act protects the gender identity of a person at all times. It also states that "person shall not be required to provide proof of a surgical procedure for total or partial genital reassignment, hormonal therapies or any other psychiatric, psychological or medical treatment to make use of the right to gender identity." The act allows parents to postpone listing gender on a child's birth certificate and prohibits “non-medically necessary treatments on the sex characteristics of a person.”<ref name="Malta Transgender Bill">{{cite web|title=Gender Identity, Gender Expression and Sex Characteristics Act (Malta, 2015)|url=http://tgeu.org/gender-identity-gender-expression-sex-characteristics-act-malta-2015/|website=Transgender Europe|access-date=2015-04-06|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150407011037/http://tgeu.org/gender-identity-gender-expression-sex-characteristics-act-malta-2015/|archive-date=2015-04-07|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="Explanation of Malta Gender Identity Law">{{cite web|title=Gender Identity, Gender Expression And Sex Characteristics Act|url=http://socialdialogue.gov.mt/en/Public_Consultations/MSDC/Pages/Consultations/GIGESC.aspx|publisher=Social Dialogue Malta|access-date=2015-04-06|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150408011911/http://socialdialogue.gov.mt/en/Public_Consultations/MSDC/Pages/Consultations/GIGESC.aspx|archive-date=2015-04-08|url-status=live}}</ref>
==In the media==
Media can contribute to trans bashing through misinformation and scare tactics. Transgender individuals are oftentimes misrepresented negatively in media, or not represented in media at all. Transgender individuals may be portrayed in the media as curiosities or oddities, as mentally unstable persons, and/ or as predators.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://content.ebscohost.com/ContentServer.asp?T=P&P=AN&K=108759276&S=R&D=a9h&EbscoContent=dGJyMNHX8kSeqLE4v%2BbwOLCmr06ep7ZSsqa4Ta6WxWXS&ContentCustomer=dGJyMPGut1C3rLZNuePfgeyx44Hy7fEA|title="Don't Talk To Me About Deception": The Necessary Erosion of the Trans* Panic Defense|last=Panfil|first=Vanessa|date=June 11, 2015|website=|publisher=|access-date=April 23, 2016}}</ref> A public example of 2015|url-status=live|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
==Trans health== According to the 2011 National Transgender Discrimination Survey Report on Health and Health Care (NTDSR), which surveyed 6,450 transgender and gender non-conforming people, people who do not identify with their birth sex face obstacles to getting healthcare and have a greater likelihood of facing health issues related to their gender identity.<ref name="2011 NTDS">{{cite web|last1=Harrison|first1=Jack|title=Injustice at Every Turn: A Report of the National Transgender Discrimination Survey|url=http://www.thetaskforce.org/static_html/downloads/reports/reports/ntds_full.pdf|website=National Gay and Lesbian Task Force|publisher=National Gay and Lesbian Task Force|access-date=2015-04-28|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150506162958/http://www.thetaskforce.org/static_html/downloads/reports/reports/ntds_full.pdf|archive-date=2015-05-06|url-status=dead}}</ref>
===Mental health===
Transgender people experience greater mental health problems, such as depression, anxiety, suicide attempts, and post traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), as well as physical [[health disparities]] (e.g., cardiovascular disease).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://web.b.ebscohost.com/ehost/pdfviewer/pdfviewer?sid=c662ff9f-e9f1-4e22-ac90-f5588f42f101%2540sessionmgr107&vid=1&hid=115|title=EBSCO Publishing Service Selection Page|website=web.b.ebscohost.com|access-date=2016-04-23}}</ref> Trans people also have a higher rate of suicide attempts than the population as a whole.<ref name="Youth Suicide Prevention Program">{{cite web|title=Statistics about Youth Suicide|url=http://www.yspp.org/about_suicide/statistics.htm|website=Youth Suicide Prevention Program|publisher=Youth Suicide Prevention Program|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150429124702/http://www.yspp.org/about_suicide/statistics.htm|archivedate=2015-04-29}}</ref> In 2013, the 2.2% of U.S. adults had attempted suicide<ref name="Suicide Attempt Rates US">{{cite web|title=Suicidal Thoughts and Suicide Attempts|url=http://www.sprc.org/basics/scope/attempts|website=Suicide Prevention Resource Center|publisher=Suicide Prevention Resource Center|access-date=2015-04-28|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150426220800/http://www.sprc.org/basics/scope/attempts|archive-date=2015-04-26|url-status=live}}</ref> while 41% of trans people had attempted suicide in 2011.<ref name="2011 NTDS" /> The rate of attempted suicide in transgender individuals increased to 51% for those bullied or harassed in school, 55% for those who recently lost a job due to bias, and 61% and 64% for those who were victims of physical and sexual assault, respectively.<ref name="2011 NTDS" /> Low self-esteem in transgender people has been linked to being at high-risk for HIV transmission.<ref name="Sugano et al. 2006">{{cite journal|last1=Sugano|first1=E|title=The impact of exposure to transphobia on HIV risk behavior in a sample of transgender women of color in San Francisco|journal=AIDS and Behavior|date=2006|volume=10|issue=2|pages=215–225|doi=10.1007/s10461-005-9040-z|pmid=16362237|s2cid=6642842}}</ref><ref name="Bockting et al. 2001">{{cite journal|last1=Bockting|first1=W|title=Transgender HIV prevention: Community involvement and empowerment|journal=Transgender and HIV: Risks, Prevention, and Care|date=2001|pages=119–144}}</ref> In 2008, the rate of HIV in transgender women in North America was 27.7%.<ref name="Herbst et al. 2008">{{cite journal|last1=Herbst|first1=J|title=Estimating HIV prevalence and risk behaviors of Male-to-Female transgender persons in the United States: A systematic review|journal=AIDS and Behavior|date=2008|volume=12|issue=1|pages=1–17|doi=10.1007/s10461-007-9299-3|pmid=17694429|s2cid=22946778|url=https://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/hal-02319357/file/Poster%20Olga%20L%20Gonzalez%202019.pdf}}</ref>
===Access to healthcare===
In the 2010 and 2011 NTDSRs, 19% of the people surveyed reported having been refused medical care due to their gender identity and 50% reported lack of provider knowledge of transgender health needs.<ref name="2011 NTDS" /><ref name="2010 NTDS">{{cite web|last1=Grant|first1=Jaime|title=National Transgender Discrimination Survey Report on Health and Health Care|url=http://www.thetaskforce.org/static_html/downloads/reports/reports/ntds_report_on_health.pdf|website=National Gay and Lesbian Task Force|publisher=National Gay and Lesbian Task Force|access-date=2015-04-28|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150507160510/http://www.thetaskforce.org/static_html/downloads/reports/reports/ntds_report_on_health.pdf|archive-date=2015-05-07|url-status=dead}}</ref> Under the Affordable Care Act, it is illegal for any health program receiving federal funding to discriminate based on gender identity. Discrimination includes refusal to admit, treat or provide any services that are available for other patients; subjection of patients to intrusive examination; harass or refuse to respond to harassment by other staff or patients; refusal to provide support services; obligation to participate in [[conversion therapy]]; and any sort of interference in the pursuit of health care rights.<ref name="ACA Accommodations">{{cite web|title=Know Your Rights Health Care|url=http://transequality.org/know-your-rights/healthcare|website=Trans Equality|publisher=Trans Equality|accessdate=28 April 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150423153629/http://transequality.org/know-your-rights/healthcare|archive-date=23 April 2015|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Racial disparities===
Race has been shown to compound manifestations of existing discrimination on the basis of gender identity.<ref name="2011 NTDS" /><ref name="2010 NTDS" /> Black trans women have the highest suicide rate of any other group in the United States, at almost half attempting in their lives, while cisgender black women attempt suicide at a rate of 1.7% on average.<ref name="AFSP Facts and Figures">{{cite web|title=Facts and Figures|url=https://www.afsp.org/understanding-suicide/facts-and-figures|website=American Foundation for Suicide Prevention|accessdate=28 April 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150423173454/http://www.afsp.org/understanding-suicide/facts-and-figures|archive-date=23 April 2015|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Trans students of color face higher rates of harassment and violence in schools.<ref name="2011 NTDS" /> American Indian transgender students face the highest rates of sexual assault in school at 24%, followed by multiracial (18%), Asian (17%), and black (15%) students. White transgender students face a 9% rate of sexual assault in K–12.<ref name="2011 NTDS" /> Black trans women have a higher rate of HIV infection than other groups, with a 30.8–56.3% rate, versus 27.7% of MTF transgender people on average.<ref name="Herbst et al. 2008" />
====Police and incarceration====
In the 2011 National Transgender Discrimination Survey, 22% of respondents who had interacted with the police reported harassment due to bias. 20% reported denial of equal services. 48% reported being uncomfortable asking for police assistance. Respondents who had served time in jail reported a higher rate of harassment by officers than by others in jail. For all respondents, 7% reported being held in a jail cell solely due to gender identity expression, while this number was 41% for black and 21% for Latino trans respondents.<ref name="2011 NTDS" /> Transgender people have reported being refused medical care, particularly hormone therapy, in prison, with black trans people and American Indian trans people with the highest reporting rates.<ref name="2011 NTDS" />
